H0.text: Checking for errors in the experimental procedure is not something the scientist will most likely do when the results of an experiment do not support the hypothesis.

H1.text: Repeat the experiment is the action a scientist will most likely not take if the results of an experiment do not support the hypothesis.

H2.text: Changing data to support the hypothesis is the action a scientist will most likely not take if the results of an experiment do not support the hypothesis.

H3.text: Asking new questions is what the scientist will most likely not do if the results of an experiment do not support the hypothesis.

A4.text: Failure of an experiment to produce interesting results may lead a scientist to reconsider the experimental method, the hypothesis, or the definition of the subject.

A5.text: The experimental control is a technique for dealing with observational error.

A7.text: The scientific method involves experimentation to test the ability of some hypothesis to adequately answer the question under investigation, which implies that failure to support a hypothesis may lead to reevaluation of the hypothesis itself.

A8.text: Manipulation checks allow investigators to isolate the chief variables to strengthen support that these variables are operating as planned.

A9.text: Proper blocking, replication, and randomization allow for the careful conduct of designed experiments.

A10.text: A 2012 survey of 2,000 psychologists found that 'the percentage of respondents who have engaged in questionable practices was surprisingly high', especially in regard to selective reporting.

A11.text: A large 2021 survey of 6,813 respondents in the Netherlands found significantly higher estimate, with 4% of the respondents engaging in data fabrication and more than half of the respondents engaging in questionable research practices.

A12.text: Should a set of data appear to be too faithful to the hypothesis, i.e., the amount of error that would normally be in such measurements does not appear, a conclusion can be drawn that the data may have been forged.

A13.text: A 2025 study from Northwestern University found that 'the publication of fraudulent science is outpacing the growth rate of legitimate scientific publications'.
